title: 109_hr4519
content: The "State High Risk Pool Funding Extension Act of 2006" extends funding for state high risk health insurance pools under the Public Health Service Act. The Secretary will provide seed grants of up to $1,000,000 to States that have not established a high risk pool. States with existing high risk pools meeting certain criteria can receive grants for operational losses. The Secretary will provide grants to States for operational losses incurred in connection with the operation of high-risk pools. The funds will be allotted based on specific criteria, with 40 percent of the appropriated amount for the fiscal year being distributed equally among qualifying States. The Secretary will provide grants to States for operational losses incurred in connection with the operation of high-risk pools. 30 percent of the appropriated amount for the fiscal year will be allotted among qualifying States based on the number of uninsured individuals in each State. The Secretary will provide grants to States for high-risk pools based on enrollment ratios and premium reductions for pools charging higher premiums. There is a special rule for pools charging over 150 percent of standard premiums, where at least 50 percent of the grant must be used to reduce premiums for enrollees. The Secretary will provide grants to States for high-risk pools based on enrollment ratios and premium reductions. States not part of the 50 States or the District of Columbia must not exceed $1,000,000 in grants. For States within the 50 States or the District of Columbia with qualified high-risk pools, the Secretary will provide grants for supplemental consumer benefits such as low-income premium subsidies. The Secretary will provide grants to States for high-risk pools based on enrollment ratios and premium reductions. States may receive benefits such as low-income premium subsidies, reduced premium trends, expanded eligibility, coverage for pre-existing conditions, increased benefits, and disease management programs. The Secretary will allot funds among qualifying States in a specified manner. The Secretary will provide grants to States for high-risk pools based on enrollment ratios and premium reductions. States may receive benefits such as low-income premium subsidies, expanded eligibility, coverage for pre-existing conditions, and disease management programs. Funds allotted to a State for a fiscal year cannot exceed 10 percent of the funds appropriated for that year. Nothing in this subsection prohibits States already implementing similar programs from being eligible for grants. For fiscal year 2006, $15,000,000 is allocated for subsection (a) and $75,000,000, with two-thirds for allotments under subsection (b)(2). Authorization of appropriations for fiscal years 2007 through 2010 includes $75,000,000 annually, with two-thirds for allotments under subsection (b)(2) and one-third for allotments under subsection (c)(3). Funds remain available for obligation through the following fiscal year. The Secretary can reallot remaining funds among States if not all amounts are allotted. States must submit an application for eligibility, and there is no entitlement to a grant under this section. The Secretary must also submit an annual report to Congress. The Secretary must submit an annual report to Congress on the distribution of grants among States and their use. Definitions include "qualified high risk pool" and "standard risk rate." The term 'standard risk rate' in the State high risk pool is determined by considering premium rates of other insurers, using actuarial techniques, and reflecting anticipated claims and expenses for coverage. The term 'State' includes all 50 states, the District of Columbia, Puerto Rico, the Virgin Islands, Guam, American Samoa, and the Northern Mariana Islands.
